CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 21, 1957, pg. 1, reads: "Child Died Here - This burned apartment tells the story of how a one-year-old boy was suffocated by smoke which filled this apartment after it caught fire while the mother 'ran down to the store to buy milk and bread.'  Two other children, ages three and five were overcome by smoke, but were revived by rescuers. - Harris Photo."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Three Fires Take Three Lives! ...The fire, in which the one-year-old boy died, apparently was caused by an open grate fire in the living room of the third-floor apartment where three children, Carol, one, Thomas, five, and Maurice, three, had been left by their mother, Mrs. Irene Williams of 1408 Whitcomb St., when she went to the store for milk and bread Tuesday evening about 9 o'clock.  The youngest child, suffocated to death, was carried out of the house.  The two older children somehow had locked themselves in the bathroom and were carried to the ground unconscious by firemen.  Patrolmen Edward Bierce and Robert Krah from Centre Ave. Police Station immediately administered oxygen to them, thus saving their lives.  Thomas was still in a serious condition at Mercy Hospital on Tuesday.  Maurice's condition was pronounced good..."
TitMainTitle: Apartment of Irene Williams after fire, with burned sofa, chair and window, 1408 Whitcomb Street, Lower Hill District

The youngest child, suffocated to death, was carried out of the house.  The two older children somehow had locked themselves in the bathroom and were carried to the ground unconscious by firemen.
